Analysis of the synovial fluid obtained during an exploratory puncture reveals :

- the presence of inflammatory joint fluid (cellularity greater than 2,000 nucleated cells/mm<sup>3</sup>, sometimes very high up to 100,000/mm<sup>3</sup>), predominantly neutrophils

- Negative results from routine bacteriological tests (possible combination!)

- Inconsistent presence of microcrystals.

question.title: What is a characteristic of the synovial fluid obtained during an exploratory puncture in microcrystalline arthropathies?
question.description: The analysis of the synovial fluid reveals a specific feature related to the presence of inflammatory cells and microcrystals.

option_a.title: The presence of a low number of nucleated cells (less than 100 cells/mm<sup>3</sup>)
option_a.description: This option describes a characteristic that is not supported by the analysis of the synovial fluid.

option_b.title: The presence of microcrystals is always consistent
option_b.description: This option is not entirely accurate, as the analysis reveals an inconsistent presence of microcrystals.

option_c.title: A high number of nucleated cells (greater than 2,000 cells/mm<sup>3</sup>)
option_c.description: This option describes a characteristic that is consistent with the analysis of the synovial fluid.

option_d.title: The absence of inflammatory cells
option_d.description: This option is not supported by the analysis of the synovial fluid, which reveals a predominance of neutrophils.
